Reviews.Title: “Good location & full of character”
Reviews.Author: saramarsdenille
Reviews.Content: We selected this hotel as we desired something central to Reforma with some distinct character, and not just a 'box standard' hotel. It certainly is a good location for exploring downtown, the historic district and Condessa. The hotel is an unusual wedge shape on a roundabout and looks quite austere from outside and the entrance area, lobby and Goudi restaurant are all also quite grand. However, we did find the rooms to be a tad on the dated side. We had booked a room with a kingsize bed on Expedia but when we checked in they did not have a king available, so after being shown a twin room, we elected to take a double room and were then moved the following day into a room with a kingsize bed. The rooms were clean and adequate, although could have benefitted from some refurbing. The bathrooms were quite small with tiny bathtubs. We enjoyed drinks in the bar area and were brought out little nibbles which we really appreciated. We did not dine in the hotel as we choose to enjoy sampling some of the restaurants around the city. There are plenty of Starbucks around the hotel, so we usually took a short walk in the morning and took in the flavour of the city vibe and a cappuccino. We did the open-top tour bus rides to see the city, although you could walk along Reforma to the a number of the historical monuments. We also walked to Condessa one day, and took the tour bus to the Pyramids from right outside the hotel. We found all the staff at the hotel to be pleasant and friendly, and although it was a pleasure to be in a part of Mexico where you do not constantly hear English, the staff had a good understanding of English (which helped us!) Our cab from the airport cost $194 pesos (a bargain we thought), and although at first wary of taking cabs we took one back from Coyocan one afternoon during rush-hour, which cost $70 on the meter, so we realized that cab fares were quite reasonable. After this we decided to try taking a cab again, but this time the driver took us a long-way round for a 5 min ride and then tried to charge us $100. This happened a second time, where we asked the driver to switch his meter on and halfway back he claimed it had stopped working (more likely switched it off), as it was reading $24 and then he tried to charge us $100. So be wary of these banditos! We took the hotel taxi back to the airport for $150.

Reviews.Title: “Prime location at low e-booked rates”
Reviews.Author: TokyoFrenchFlyer
Reviews.Content: Clean, gracious and efficient. A quick walk to the historic center (but no really convenient Metro station at hand, as there is no line that follows Paseo de la Reforma). Before accepting room: verify that strongbox (no charge) is operational and, if you care, verify that refrigerator is operational, too. Good hot water (shower and tub) and excellent beds. You will not be able to get a radio-taxi from here, unless you call it yourself. There are a few English- and Japanese-speaking drivers attached to the hotel, so-called "taxi turistica." These are pleasant and friendly but don't offer best rates unless you insist beforehand. NB, in Mexico City it is NOT advisable to hail taxis on the street. The buffet breakfast is ample but for much less you can order coffee, coffee with milk, or tea and delicious sweet rolls, if that is all you require. There is a Sanborns mini-department store across Reforma and several adjacent convenience stores for beer, snacks, and other needs. Don't forget to have your shoes shined on the street for a dollar. Be generous and pay with a 20-peso note. You could never achieve this brilliant shine yourself. Don't try it at home. The Hotel Emporio down the street is also a good bet, with a jacuzzi in each room. Except for traffic noise, both these hotels are respectable, quiet, and helpful. The State-run arts and crafts shop with fixed prices, FonArt is just down the street same side.

Reviews.Title: “An aging dowager is well worth the price of admission”
Reviews.Author: Tacklow
Reviews.Content: Though the self-bestowed 5 stars are a little on the generous side, nevertheless the Hotel Imperial is a great place to stay. The lobby, upstairs restaurant and friendly and accommodating staff rate full marks. The bedrooms have been modified from their original colonial decor and are a bit of a mixed bag. The first time we stayed, the coat rack bar and hangers were missing as were the little luxuries (such as Kleenex tissues). The second time, everything was in order. Noise from the street (if you want to have the window open) is fairly intrusive as is to be expected from the location in the heart of the commercial district. Museums, the cathedral, the 'zocalo' are all a short distance away and the rates on both of our previous visits (booked in advance over the internet) were at least half of the rack rate. Highly recommended!

Reviews.Title: “Great central location; fantastic staff”
Reviews.Author: Mirandasyndrome
Reviews.Content: A friend and I stayed at this lovely historic hotel in September 2011. It was walking distance to the MONUMENTO A LA REVOLUCIÓN and Mercado Artesanal de la Ciudadela. There's a Sanborn's across the street and a few good restaurants (including the hotel restaurant) in the vicinity. What struck us was how helpful the staff were. I left my cell phone in a cab on the way to the airport. The phone was returned to the hotel and then they held on to it until I could send for it once I arrived home. Room service is prompt and courteous as was bell staff. Rooms are basic but clean and comfortable. I highly recommend a stay here while you explore this gorgeous city.

Reviews.Title: “Hotel Imperial Reforma - again!”
Reviews.Author: HermanTheGerman-inTX
Reviews.Content: I returned to Mexico City - and I returned to the Imperial. The four years gone by were kind to the hotel. Not much has changed - either way: The Hotel Imperial is a beautiful hotel, that still has kept its charm from the turn of the century - the 19th that is. The luxury has somewhat faded from the days it housed presidents and diplomats. The hotel's location on Reforma boulevard at the Cristobal Colon traffic circle puts it in the middle between the historic district/Alameda and Zona Rosa/Chapultepec Park. Metro stations for line 1 and 2 and 3 are within 10 minutes walking distance. I made the walk fromn the hotel all the way to the Zocalo via Bellas Artes and to Chapultepec Park along the monuments, statues, and various art pieces to be done in 30 minutes each -or less, and quite pleasant. A friendly staff is helpful and most speak English. The lobby, bar, restaurant and cafe areas are pleasant and appointed with taste. You have entered a 3 to 4 star hotel (on a 1-5 scale). I had booked a king room (for one person). I had requested a room on an upper floor to escape traffic noise (especially on the Morelos Blvd side), which was obliged. To receive a functioning A/C and refrigerator presented a challenge and 1.5 hour waiting. The room's furniture resembled more 2 star accommodations. The room was clean, the furniture functional. A hard mattress (the aztecs didn't sleep on anything softer either!), dresser, desk, round table, a couple of chairs and a few pictures. Ample closet space with a built-in safe (get lock from receptionist). You will find hotel branded accoutrements everywhere. The stationary, toiletries - all had the Imperial Hotel's logo. The A/C produced about 65-70 degrees on high fan speed. It was October and 75-80 degrees outside - so I am not complaining about lack of A/C. I just don't know if it would work when it's hotter. The bathroom: stone counter and tiles everywhere, plenty of towels, 2 bottles of water every day, plenty of toiletries, a shower enclosure over the tub. Though shall not walk on that carpet with light colored socks - enough said! I go to Mexico City to enjoy art, history and cutlure, not to spend too much time in my hotel room. But - it would have been nice to have more than one or two English speaking channels on the TV (get remote control from receptionist), but then - you have not lived until you watched the Simpson in Mexish. A reliable wake up call got me going at 4:00 am to catch the return flight and the bell man had a taxi cab waiting for the airport ride (180 pesos = $15). Numerous restaurants and shops are in the immediate vicinity. Sanborn's accross the street is a small department store with a "quite ok" restaurant - open until 1 am. A convenience store is next door to the hotel, (they have your cold beer, cappucino, snacks), bakeries, cantinas, more restaurants, Banks/ATMs, etc are very close. I did eat once in the hotel's Cafe (afternoon buffet, 165 pesos) the food was "pretty good" - but repeated itself day after day as I observed. Waiters were somewhat inattentive. The lobby/restaurant bar seems stocked well - and has the best ice cubes I ever had. Check it out and you will see what I mean. In summary: I paid $50 per night (incl. tax and fees, through a lonely travel website), and I had safe and satisfactory accommodations in an excellent location. I had done extensive research on this and many other hotel websites and could not find a better value in the center of Mexico City. Should I return with my spouse/fiancee/secretary and want to "impress", I would go to the next level and select the Camino Real at Chapultepec Park for twice the money. But I am glad that I did not pick the lower priced options off Reforma, in Zona Rosa or in the historic districts. I walked by some of those and I was glad that I did not save the $10 or $20. The Imperial surprises nicely in some areas, disappoints in others. The Hotel Imperial was a satisfactory choice that gave me my monies worth and then some. With a little investment and consistency by hotel management, this could be a prime selection for the financially conscious, yet amenity oriented traveller.

Reviews.Title: “Losing its luster”
Reviews.Author: jjcpeter
Reviews.Content: Decent location, though busy and quite noisy. Standard room was a generous size, but the air conditioning didn't work and neither did half the lamps. Used both the restaurant (Gaudi) and Room Service, with very satisfactory food quality and service. Staff were very pleasant and helpful. Booked the room one day in advance and benefitted from a low low rate on hotels.com. For the price, it was OK. September, 2011

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel for the price”
Reviews.Author: rainbow16
Reviews.Content: This hotel has pleasant staff, and a great location. You can walk to the Zocalo in about 30 minutes. The rooms are large and well furnished.

Reviews.Title: “Great bargain”
Reviews.Author: hop0409
Reviews.Content: We were looking for a hotel that was reasonable, and at the same time decent. This hotel satisfied those requirements. It's old, and the rooms do reflect that, but for the most part everything was very satisfactory. We got a great room on the first floor (in Mexico, the ground floor is the ground floor, and the next floor up which in the states would be the second floor is the first floor) and we even had a balcony. There was air conditioning and a nice shower. One negative: we were located right above the bar, so it smelled smokey. But keeping the door to the balcony open helped with that.

Reviews.Title: “Good hotel - useless wifi!”
Reviews.Author: brendaontravels
Reviews.Content: This is a conveniently located hotel, it is easy to get to all main historic attractions. It is clean, comfortable, the bedrooms are spacious. However, the hotel's reference to free wifi, means no wifi. It doesn't work, out of 27 wireless networks in the area, 8 belong to Imperial, and in a 10 day stay I managed only to connect - probably by luck - 4 times. Do not be fooled. Restaurant serves buffet style breakfast at additional cost, always edible but luke warm. I left the hotel feedback about the defiency of their wifi...that aside, I would stay again, but eat at VIPs which is about a 8 minute walk up the road.

Reviews.Title: “nice hotel, a little old”
Reviews.Author: chrisf29
Reviews.Content: This hotel wasn't bad. It was clean and the staff was nice. It's a little old, but I kind of liked that. It is a hike to the closest metro though, about 20 minutes, which is kind of annoying. The first floor is only smoking rooms also, so if you want non-smoking and they put you on the first floor, ask to change because the rooms are stinky. We also stayed at Hotel Fontan, and I would recommend that hotel over this one because of a more convenient location and it's about the same price.

Reviews.Title: “do not sleep in this nest”
Reviews.Author: ViaggiatoreNY
Reviews.Content: I am not a difficult person and i always prefer to save money on hotel so i never expect too much but this one is very bad.From the first day i had cockroaches in my room, the first 2 days i just killed them without saying a word as i did not care much, the third day i saw 5 of them happily running in the bathroom so i decided to call the reception. The manager came after few minutes saying that she was going to spray, the same day, at night i saw again 3 of them, obviously they did not do anything. The same night, for the second time, i had also to call someone to unblock the wc as for the second time in 3 days it was badly blocked, the all night not a nice smell was coming out from the bathroom. I called again the reception and the manager came again in few minutes and this is the best part, she came as she wanted to see the bugs ( surely they were waiting for her ), she did not believe me and she said i was the only one complaining! about the bathroom it was my fault again as i used too much paper, at the end it was my fault for everything. The next morning i killed again 5 bugs and closed them inside a film roll i gave them at the reception for the manager...never heard back from her, not apologies not room change nothing!!!! The hotel is a nest and the manager doesn't care at all! i am a travel photographer and i shot pictures of this, i will make sure to show this to all the editors i will meet to avoid other customers to sleep on a nest. Plus,one side of the hotel is right on one of the most busy avenue of Mexico City, so, do not expect to sleep well and the rooms don't have a wireless connection as they advertise.

Reviews.Title: “Looks good in the outside, but the rooms are not so pretty.”
Reviews.Author: dandelion_hds
Reviews.Content: I decided to stay there because I got a great deal with my flights and it is close to my family's house. When I arrived, the service was good at the front desk, but later in one of the restaurants above it was slow. I went to my room and it looked like a room from an old house. The beds were soooo hard, thank god i was super tired when I went to sleep because they were really uncomfortable, the bathroom was old and the housekeeper wouldn't replace our water bottles. I didn't spend too much time at the hotel because I was all day spending time with my family. It served its purpose. I needed a place to stay and close to my family. It is on a great location, but I will never stay there again. I recommend the Fiesta Americana which is a block away, it has a Starbuck and it is a lot nicer.

Reviews.Title: “Great place to access all Mexico City has to offer, but splurge on the bigger room”
Reviews.Author: Meels12
Reviews.Content: This was an ideal location for walking to the Zocalo, Bosque & museums, artisan market, and restaurants. The room and bed were very small, so next time I would splurge on a larger room with a larger bed because we didn't sleep that well. But overall, Mexico City was a wonderful place to visit, it had so much culture and history to offer, we could have stayed a month! We felt very safe the whole time, and the people were so hospitable. We ate street food everyday, which was DELICIOUS. I highly recommend it here.

Reviews.Title: “Good value for money”
Reviews.Author: Kazza08
Reviews.Content: The hotel itself is perhaps a little bit worn, but the rooms are spacious and clean. Although our room was facing the busy avenida Reforma, the room was surprisingly quiet (it helped that it was on the 6th floor!). The area directly around the hotel itself is perhaps a little bit boring, but the Zona Rosa is right around the corner, and the Zocalo a not too intimidating walk away. We paid approx. 520 pesos a night, and for this standard hotel we found it good value.

Reviews.Title: “In the heart of Mexico-city”
Reviews.Author: duskrider
Reviews.Content: We (I and my wife) stayed in this hotel for two nights. The hotel have unusual shape â€“ inner space is triangular, and itâ€™s looking impressively. This hotel is situated very good, right on one of most important streets of Mexico DF, close to Centro Historico and Anthropology museum. This, and very attractive price (only 43$ with online booking) has defined our choice. The staff was very friendly. But there are some minuses: rooms are old enough, and theyâ€™re a little noisy.

Reviews.Title: “Large Rooms, Friendly Service for Great Value”
Reviews.Author: Filmgal
Reviews.Content: My partner and I stayed here for 2 nights in May 2010. For under $40 CDN a night, the hotel was a bargain. Very large, clean room, friendly staff, and good location on Reforma right near a Turibus stop. A room was ready and we were able to check in early at 11am. Our room faced Reforma but we did not have any problems with traffic noise and got a quiet night's sleep both nights. The lobby is beautiful, and the rooms, thought dated, were comfortable with fridge, TV, and shower/tub combo. We did not have any problems with noise echoing through the open concept lobby and floors. There was safe in the room but it did not have a lock, and a doorman was stationed at the hotel entrance what appeared to be overnight. The hotel was easy to located for taxi drivers and tours. Breakfast was a little steep for what you get in a buffet, but was satisfactory. The Spanish restaurant Gaudi on-site is also decent. There is a Starbucks and a convenience store near the hotel as well and felt safe walking to and from the hotel. The hotel will call you a taxi but be cautioned it is not a metered taxi, but a hotel taxi so negotiate a price before getting in. There is a business centre with internet, as well as free wifi. The wifi didn't work very well in the room, but had a strong signal in the open hallways (each floor also has a seating area).

Reviews.Title: “A really nice stay”
Reviews.Author: unclecofie
Reviews.Content: Stayed here for four nights on a visit to DF. The deal I got online was US$45 per night, and it was well worth it. The online reservation service hadn't sent in my reservation, but the desk staff was very nice and went to a great deal of trouble to look into. They even let me get onto the Internet in the business center for free and print some copies to look into this snafu. The hotel is 100 years old, but don't expect any charm inside the building. It looks like it was last redecorated in 1982, so that was a little disappointing. The room however was modern, clean and comfortable. Half of the queen size mattress was not so good, so you might want to check your mattress first thing on check-in. Fortunately I was by myself, so I just stayed on the good side of the bed. The only other criticisms of the room were dim lighting and a complete lack of any English-language TV channels. Some CNN would have been nice. Downstairs, the breakfast buffet is about US$8 and had a large selection of fresh fruit and juices, as well as a large selection of continental, American and Mexican foods. It's far more for far less than what you'll find for breakfast at one of the nearby chains like VIP's or Sanborns. I noticed the fancy dining room, Gaudi, was always deserted during dinner, so I took that as a sign that it must not be that great. The location is a big plus, right on the Reforma and an easy walk to bo the Centro Historico and the Zona Rosa. Lots of good dining within walking distance. The nearest Metro station is a bit of a hike but not too terrible. Overall, a really good deal considering you get a nice room in a great location.

Reviews.Title: “A friendly hotel grand building in a great location”
Reviews.Author: Morpethite
Reviews.Content: Found this hotel (through Trip Advisor) to fill in our first night when we couldn't get into the nearby Melia which was the designated conference hotel. On balance the reviews then were favourable and it was very close so we chanced it...and regretted that we didn't stay there exclusively! Staff were very helpful and the first floor restaurant (former ballroom) was superb - a beautiful setting and the chefs and waiters went out of their way to accomodate : we went back for dinner every night but one. Much cheaper , much more character - and we thought much better overall - than the usual international chains!

Reviews.Title: “Amazing,felt like I was at home.”
Reviews.Author: starfl
Reviews.Content: This was my first travel to Mexico,at first I was a little skeptical about the fact that this hotel was built in 1904,but I was impressed when I got there,the outside as well as the inside are kept very well and as close to original as possible down to the clock that stands in front of the hotel in perfect working order,the rooms were clean,the beds were a little hard,it has central ac,a safe in the room.The hotel is very well positioned between the zona rosa and the historic center.I would like to use this forum to thank all the staff,Alicia from housekeeping,my son got sick and she was very helpful told us about a clinic where to take him and was very conforting and supportive to my wife,Julio and all the other guys from parking they were my GPS and guide,the concierge guys all shifts.Sorry I can't remember all the names.I spent 11 days at this hotel and the only thing I would change is the bed for a softer one.100% recommend it.any questions e-mail me hpcache@gmail.com

Reviews.Title: “Very nice hotel...”
Reviews.Author: TheeGrCERO
Reviews.Content: Going into Mexico City with reservations for Imperial Reforma I was a little nervous from some negative reviews. Upon arrival, I was immediatelly relieved. Hotel Imperial was in excellent repair, clean, and the service was good. I certainly would stay there again and do recommend it, for the money, it's an excellent choice. My only complaint would be about the beds being a bit stiff, but nothing that a couple blankets didn't fix.

Reviews.Title: “Warning to travelers”
Reviews.Author: unltdmind
Reviews.Content: I just returned from Mexico and spent my last 3 nights at the Imperial. The business office use and internet was free - a great asset for me - the breakfast buffet included in our group's package was fabulous and most of the staff was very friendly and helpful.There were several members of our group who complained that their personal bags and suitcases had been ruffled through and some items were missing, including a cell phone. We checked out of the hotel one day early because of these incidences and also because the maint. department began a painting project that filled the entire atrium and thus the rooms with a very intense turpentine odor. We requested that they cease until after we departed. They agreed but continued to paint anyway. The next day we left the hotel when the odor was extremely bad and members of the group found personal items missing, but were unable to find another hotel that day for one night to accomodate the entire group. The Imperial promised to deal with the issues we presented. So we returned for the last night. The painting started again and it was the very last morning, during a meeting, when my own jewelry disappeared. I believe it to be a housekeeping management problem, and not the housekeepers necessarily. I hope to find resolution with them, but write this review prior to the end of this incident because the hotel administration appears to be accomodating but the behavior continues.

Reviews.Title: “Charming and clean”
Reviews.Author: markomagare
Reviews.Content: I stayed here for five nights in November 2007 and it was my first visit to Mexico. I chose this hotel mainly for its location (on Paseo de la Reforma, within walking distance to both the Zocalo, Zona Rosa and the Anthropology museum) and didn't regret my choice for one second. The hotel is in a charming building as you can see on the pictures, the room was spatious and clean with air-conditioning and a large bathroom. It was also surprisingly quiet considering that it overlooked la Reforma. The breakfast buffet was excellent, but I didn't try the restaurant on other meals, spending my days and evenings out. The personnel were extremely helpful, and there is also a tourist office in the hotel which arranged tours to Teotihuacan and to Puebla for me. Overall, a charming place, highly recommended for those who need a nice place to stay with helpful staff and a comfortable room, and can do without all the hightech amenities like free wifi that big hotel chains offer. NB - The price was 50 euros per night which is certainly a lot less than the 135 dollars currently indicated on tripadvisor..

Reviews.Title: “Classic”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Classic hotel inaugurated by Porfirio Diaz in 1904. Completely refurbished and air conditioned in 1956. Excellent location right on Reforma, near Juarez and just a few blocks from the Metro on Balderas. Elegant high ceilings, excellent service and a good restaurant; bathrooms with showers over tubs. Reasonable prices and seasonal special offers.

Reviews.Title: “Great potential, needs work”
Reviews.Author: calgalLosAngeles
Reviews.Content: This hotel has a lot of potential, the exterior and lobby (per the internet ) looked great and that proved to be true, however, the lack of attention to details made it a very average experience. Dirty Carpets, chandeliers and rust around the bathroom fixtures and not replacing the bottled water we consumed were a few of these examples. Additionally, the ample jacuzzi tub looked like it had not been cleaned, therefore, we avoided use. The bedroom curtains facing the street did not close, this compounded the street and traffic noise. The bedding was sparse for the cool weather and they certainly could have used some comforters or at least additional blankets. The mattresses were hard & we had to ask for additional pillows. The staff was inexperienced and incognitant of directions or surrounding area restaurants aside from the extremely overpriced below average hotel restaurant. We did have a great (hotel arranged) tour guide to the pyramids, ballet folklorica and the floating gardens which I would highly recommend. With a little bit of TLC this place could be a great hotel, it just need to be tweeked!

Reviews.Title: “Delight”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This quietly elegant hotel is a former presidential home and later, embassy. The building is wonderful, the service extremely helpful and the location is great. Our large suite with jacuzzi had a terrific view of Reforma and was more than reasonably priced. We are delighted with our choice of hotel and have quite possibly found a new "home" in Mexico City.
